title: How to Make Dinner Rolls

steps.headline: In a saucepan, combine the water and shortening or butter.
steps.description: Heat until the temperature reaches 120 to 130° F (50 to 55° C). Check the temperature with an instant read thermometer. Don't have a thermometer? The water is ready about a minute after it hits the definitely-hot-but-I'm-not-burning-myself stage. At 120° the water is touchable. At about 130°, it hits the point where you can't touch it without burning yourself. You want it somewhere in that frame.

steps.headline: Get out your mixing bowl and heavy-duty mixer.
steps.description: You know -- one of those ones with a dough hook, like a KitchenAid. It can be done without one, but your forearms are gonna be aching in the morning. That dough hook will make everything much easier.

steps.headline: Add the dry milk powder, yeast, sugar, salt and flour to bowl.
steps.description: On low speed, combine the dry ingredients until they are well combined.

steps.headline: Add the warm water and egg, mixing until a soft dough starts to form.
steps.description: Make sure the egg is fully incorporated into the dough.

steps.headline: Add more flour, if needed, to make a soft dough.
steps.description: The dough should be slightly sticky or tacky, only lightly sticking to your fingers when you touch it.

steps.headline: Knead the dough, using the dough hook, until satiny.
steps.description: This should take about 5 minutes. Obviously it'll take longer if you're doing it by hand.

steps.headline: Turn out your dough into a clean mixing bowl and cover with plastic wrap.
steps.description: Leave it to rise for about 10 minutes on the counter or on top of the stove. A "warmish" spot is ideal.

steps.headline: When 10 minutes is up, remove the wrap, spray your hands with nonstick cooking spray and punch down the dough.
steps.description: For the bread to adequately rise in the oven, it needs to go through two rounds of rising beforehand.

steps.headline: Shape dough as desired.
steps.description: To make old-fashioned pan rolls, pinch off dough the size of a small ball, comfortably fitting in the palm of your hand. Roll the ball of dough between your hands until rounded perfectly. Continue until all the dough is shaped into dinner rolls of roughly the same size. This recipe should warrant 12-15 rolls.

steps.headline: Place rolls in a baking pan sprayed with nonstick cooking spray and let rise.
steps.description: You want them to almost double in size -- which should take about 30 to 45 minutes. While you're waiting for this, preheat the oven to 375° to 400°F (190° to 200°C).

steps.headline: Bake rolls until golden brown, about 15 minutes.
steps.description: Then, if you'd like, take them out of the oven and brush the tops with melted butter for extra flavor and softness. And then serve almost immediately. Brush with butter if you'd like, not take them out of the oven if you'd like. Well, you could keep them in the oven, but then you'd never be able to eat them, so where's the fun in that?

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F.
steps.description: In 1/2 cup of warm water, dissolve your yeast -- right in the glass measuring cup. Set aside while you move onto creating the dough.

steps.headline: Cream the butter and honey in your mixer with the paddle attachment.
steps.description: A stand mixer is best -- that thing is literally going to be your bread and butter. Without it, you'll be mixing till the cows come home. Which is, for the record, a long ways away.

steps.headline: Add the eggs and mix together, scraping down the sides regularly.
steps.description: Add the milk and yeast mixture, still stirring. Make sure it's all evenly and thoroughly combined.

steps.headline: Add the flour and salt, mixing until combined.
steps.description: Change to the dough hook and knead for 2-3 minutes only -- just until no longer tacky, adding a tablespoon or two of flour, if needed to sop up any extra moisture. Stick your finger in it -- if there's a bit of stick and a bit of residue, you're in the bread zone.

steps.headline: Allow it to sit in the bowl, covered, for one hour.
steps.description: It needs time to rise and the yeast to take action. When the time is up, place it on a floured surface and knead it a couple of times, then let it rest for 3 more minutes. Plastic wrap works well, though you can also throw a towel over it if you're in a pinch.

steps.headline: Place balls of dough into a buttered 13×9-inch baking dish.
steps.description: They should be divided into 24 equal pieces and the pieces should be touching. Don't worry -- they'll get bigger! You can grease or spray the pan, too, for the record.

steps.headline: Cover the pan and let rise for 1 hour.
steps.description: This is the second round of rising the dough needs to go through to reach the appropriate size. Leave it on the counter or on the stove while you go about your day.

steps.headline: Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown.
steps.description: When they're finished, take them out of the oven and brush a thing layer of butter on the tops of the rolls to give them that perfectly done, golden sheen. And then serve!

steps.headline: Heat your oven to 400°F and spray a muffin tin with cooking spray.
steps.description: This recipe makes about 1 1/2 dozen rolls of moderate size. If you don't have a muffin tin, you can use a 13x9-inch pan instead.

steps.headline: In a 3-quart saucepan, stir the milk, sugar and olive oil together.
steps.description: Bring it to a simmer over medium heat, stirring occasionally.

steps.headline: Once it's simmering, turn off the heat and allow it to cool until warm.
steps.description: Ideally, it'll be somewhere between 90°F and 110°F -- definitely warm, but not too hot to touch. This should take about 10 minutes. If you place the tip of your finger in the liquid and hold it there, you should be fine. Don't try this too soon! The last thing you want is to burn yourself.

steps.headline: Add the flour and the yeast to the mixture.
steps.description: Once it's blended, cover it and let it rise for about an hour. It should nearly double in size. Plastic wrap is best, but a towel will work too.

steps.headline: Stir in the remaining flour, baking soda, baking powder, minced rosemary and salt.
steps.description: Combine it well until it looks like a perfect bread dough.

steps.headline: Roll 1-inch balls of dough in your hands.
steps.description: You should end up with 54 small balls. Calm down -- place three balls into each muffin cup. We're not making rolls for an army, here.

steps.headline: Push 1 slice of brie into the middle of each filled muffin cup.
steps.description: You'll want to tuck most of it under the tops of the dough balls, so when it bakes it doesn't crust on top. You want that cheesy goodness preserved!

steps.headline: Bake 16 to 20 minutes or until golden brown.
steps.description: If any cheese overflows from the tin, spoon it back onto the rolls. You want them cheesy, right?

steps.headline: Cool for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Transfer to a cooling rack to allow to cool completely. Then try not to eat them all!

text: Traditional Dinner Rolls In a saucepan, combine the water and shortening or butter. Heat until the temperature reaches 120 to 130° F (50 to 55° C). Check the temperature with an instant read thermometer. Don't have a thermometer? The water is ready about a minute after it hits the definitely-hot-but-I'm-not-burning-myself stage. At 120° the water is touchable. At about 130°, it hits the point where you can't touch it without burning yourself. You want it somewhere in that frame. Get out your mixing bowl and heavy-duty mixer. You know -- one of those ones with a dough hook, like a KitchenAid. It can be done without one, but your forearms are gonna be aching in the morning. That dough hook will make everything much easier. Add the dry milk powder, yeast, sugar, salt and flour to bowl. On low speed, combine the dry ingredients until they are well combined. Add the warm water and egg, mixing until a soft dough starts to form. Make sure the egg is fully incorporated into the dough. Add more flour, if needed, to make a soft dough. The dough should be slightly sticky or tacky, only lightly sticking to your fingers when you touch it. Knead the dough, using the dough hook, until satiny. This should take about 5 minutes. Obviously it'll take longer if you're doing it by hand. Turn out your dough into a clean mixing bowl and cover with plastic wrap. Leave it to rise for about 10 minutes on the counter or on top of the stove. A "warmish" spot is ideal. When 10 minutes is up, remove the wrap, spray your hands with nonstick cooking spray and punch down the dough. For the bread to adequately rise in the oven, it needs to go through two rounds of rising beforehand. Shape dough as desired. To make old-fashioned pan rolls, pinch off dough the size of a small ball, comfortably fitting in the palm of your hand. Roll the ball of dough between your hands until rounded perfectly. Continue until all the dough is shaped into dinner rolls of roughly the same size. This recipe should warrant 12-15 rolls. Place rolls in a baking pan sprayed with nonstick cooking spray and let rise. You want them to almost double in size -- which should take about 30 to 45 minutes. While you're waiting for this, preheat the oven to 375° to 400°F (190° to 200°C). Bake rolls until golden brown, about 15 minutes. Then, if you'd like, take them out of the oven and brush the tops with melted butter for extra flavor and softness. And then serve almost immediately. Brush with butter if you'd like, not take them out of the oven if you'd like. Well, you could keep them in the oven, but then you'd never be able to eat them, so where's the fun in that? Whole Wheat Dinner Rolls Preheat your oven to 350°F. In 1/2 cup of warm water, dissolve your yeast -- right in the glass measuring cup. Set aside while you move onto creating the dough. Cream the butter and honey in your mixer with the paddle attachment. A stand mixer is best -- that thing is literally going to be your bread and butter. Without it, you'll be mixing till the cows come home. Which is, for the record, a long ways away. Add the eggs and mix together, scraping down the sides regularly. Add the milk and yeast mixture, still stirring. Make sure it's all evenly and thoroughly combined. Add the flour and salt, mixing until combined. Change to the dough hook and knead for 2-3 minutes only -- just until no longer tacky, adding a tablespoon or two of flour, if needed to sop up any extra moisture. Stick your finger in it -- if there's a bit of stick and a bit of residue, you're in the bread zone. Allow it to sit in the bowl, covered, for one hour. It needs time to rise and the yeast to take action. When the time is up, place it on a floured surface and knead it a couple of times, then let it rest for 3 more minutes. Plastic wrap works well, though you can also throw a towel over it if you're in a pinch. Place balls of dough into a buttered 13×9-inch baking dish. They should be divided into 24 equal pieces and the pieces should be touching. Don't worry -- they'll get bigger! You can grease or spray the pan, too, for the record. Cover the pan and let rise for 1 hour. This is the second round of rising the dough needs to go through to reach the appropriate size. Leave it on the counter or on the stove while you go about your day. Bake for 20-25 minutes until golden brown. When they're finished, take them out of the oven and brush a thing layer of butter on the tops of the rolls to give them that perfectly done, golden sheen. And then serve! Rosemary & Brie Dinner Rolls Heat your oven to 400°F and spray a muffin tin with cooking spray. This recipe makes about 1 1/2 dozen rolls of moderate size. If you don't have a muffin tin, you can use a 13x9-inch pan instead. In a 3-quart saucepan, stir the milk, sugar and olive oil together. Bring it to a simmer over medium heat, stirring occasionally. Once it's simmering, turn off the heat and allow it to cool until warm. Ideally, it'll be somewhere between 90°F and 110°F -- definitely warm, but not too hot to touch. This should take about 10 minutes. If you place the tip of your finger in the liquid and hold it there, you should be fine. Don't try this too soon! The last thing you want is to burn yourself. Add the flour and the yeast to the mixture. Once it's blended, cover it and let it rise for about an hour. It should nearly double in size. Plastic wrap is best, but a towel will work too. Stir in the remaining flour, baking soda, baking powder, minced rosemary and salt. Combine it well until it looks like a perfect bread dough. Roll 1-inch balls of dough in your hands. You should end up with 54 small balls. Calm down -- place three balls into each muffin cup. We're not making rolls for an army, here. Push 1 slice of brie into the middle of each filled muffin cup. You'll want to tuck most of it under the tops of the dough balls, so when it bakes it doesn't crust on top. You want that cheesy goodness preserved! Bake 16 to 20 minutes or until golden brown. If any cheese overflows from the tin, spoon it back onto the rolls. You want them cheesy, right? Cool for 10 minutes. Transfer to a cooling rack to allow to cool completely. Then try not to eat them all!
